awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Therapeutic Machine-Learned Triage Application For Early Detection and Triage of COPD Exacerbations
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of SBIR Phase II project aims to reduce significant disease flare-ups in patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), increase in-patient quality-of-life, and reduce expensive and unnecessary healthcare utilization. COPD is one of the leading chronic conditions driving potentially avoidable hospital admissions, accounting for an estimated $25 B in 2018 patient care costs. Current at-home care support for COPD patients is often completely missing or consists of action plans that fail to provide effective, individualized care.  Integrating health management and a smart triage system offering instant healthcare guidance has the potential to reduce unnecessary COPD hospitalization and provide long-term maintenance treatment of COPD symptoms. The proposed project will develop an easy-to use, personalized triage application that catches disease degeneration early, tracks patient health history, and provides decision support to guide patients appropriately.   Moreover, an easily accessible, highly accurate, convenient solution can empower patients to make better health decisions early. 

This SBIR Phase II project focuses on optimizing and deploying a triage application that provides personalized decision support and therapeutic benefit to patients with COPD. The proposed project will validate this application for a new population and test the integrated system.  Specific technical tasks include the expansion of algorithms to include jointly diagnosed COPD-asthma patients, an important population at risk, as well as optimization of configurations for usability and performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
COPD hospitalization accounted for $25 billion of the massive $70 billion in 2018 patient care costs. Exacerbations are the leading cause for new prescription medications, ER visits, and hospital admissions. The consistently poor availability of effective at-home therapeutic tools has given rise to severe economic burden and growing global mortality. The mobile app prototyped, optimized, and tested in this NSF phase 2 SBIR - is a patient/clinician facing mobile application powered by machine-learned prediction models that individuals can use to track their COPD related symptoms and signs and intervene on potential exacerbations before they rise to the level of emergency care. The technology was built to transform at-home COPD management and reduce health utilization costs in a large segment of the 13-15 million diagnosed COPD patients in the United States alone.

In this study, we successfully developed and validated a set of machine-learned, COPD specific, triage algorithms that were shown (in peer-reviewed studies) to perform better than existing standard-of-care (currently, when patients are concerned about new symptoms and/or health problems, they speak with a nurse practitioner, internist, pulmonologist, or emergency care specialist to triage their problem). These algorithms were subsequently deployed in a mobile application and tested in a population of COPD patients for usability, adoption, and potential health benefit. The mobile app development process was extensive and included iterative prototyping inclusive of patient feedback and outcome testing. App feature engineering included oximetry tracking, installation of pollution tracking and medication selecting APIs, foreign language translation, optimization of front-end UI and backend execution (for speed). Once completed, the prototype was subjected to human testing via SBIR funding and established early evidence of strong adoption and usability modalities in addition to preliminary markers of health benefit indicating improved anxiety and reduced symptom severity among users. Future randomized control studies would need to be done to establish a statistically and clinically significant benefit associated with use of the mobile application for the purpose of commercialization as a digital therapy.

Finally, the theory underlying the machine learning prediction models developed under SBIR funding is highly robust and has been the source of 2 peer reviewed publications and nearly 10 conference proceedings papers/talks. This outcome is quite significant as one of the major missions of the NSF is to fund research activities in which the core science is, in addition to being novel and validated, generalizable to other fields of scientific inquiry. In this manner, both the machine-learning modeling methodologies and the synthetic data generation schemes developed and published through this NSF SBIR project are highly robust and have implications in climate science, financial markets, and other healthcare studies.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2021
Modified by: Sumanth Swaminathan
